ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Annealing-induced changes of the 3.31 eV emission in ZnO nanorods

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials, Department of Materials Science and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The effect of annealing on the 3.31 eV (A line) emission in ZnO nanorods is studied in detail by temperature-dependent photoluminescence (PL). Annealing results in obvious changes in peak energy and lineshape of the A line, indicating different luminescence origin in the as-grown and annealed ZnO nanorods. In the as-grown nanorods, the A line is a result of competition between free-to-neutral acceptor (FA) transition and the first longitude optical phonon replica of free exciton (FX-1LO) recombination. While for the annealed nanorods, FA transition disappears and the A line is attributed to FX-1LO only. In combination with trace impurity analysis, the results allow us to conclude that the acceptor involved in the FA transition is stacking faults rather than unintentional acceptor impurities.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: One-dimensional (1D) ZnO nanostructures (nanowires and nanorods) are considered as a promising building block for nanoscale optoelectronic devices, in particular light-emitting devices [1], due to their simple and controllable growth and excellent optical properties, in particular large exciton binding energy of 60 meV. In this regard, photoluminescence (PL) properties of 1D ZnO nanostructures are of extreme importance and have been extensively investigated [2–6]. In the near band edge (NBE) region, an emission line around 3.31 eV (generally denoted as the A line) at low temperature has been frequently observed in various ZnO samples [7]. At room temperature it red-shifts to about 3.26 eV and sometimes dominates the NBE region of the PL spectra. Many researchers take it for granted that it is an excitonic emission without checking its features at low temperature. In fact, its origin has been a controversial topic for a long time. So far several candidates have been invoked, including the first longitudinal optical phonon replica of free exciton (FX-1LO), free-to-neutral acceptor (FA) transition, surface exciton, etc. (see Ref. [7] for a detailed discussion). In particular, some researchers attributed it to acceptor bound excitons in p-type ZnO. Recently, Schirra et al. [7] presented convincing evidences that the A line in their samples is related to stacking faults, while Tainoff et al. [8] suggested that it is a result of competition between FX-1LO and FA. It seems that several different transitions with very close energies are responsible for the A line, and the origin of A line is sample-dependent. Therefore, it is necessary to figure out the dependence of each transition on the conditions of growth and post-growth treatment.

In this work, we investigate the effects of thermal annealing on the A line in nominally undoped ZnO nanorods using low-temperature PL and trace elemental analysis. Annealing results in significant change of the lineshape and peak energy of the A line. Temperature-dependent PL results indicate that there is competition between FA and FX-1LO transitions in the as-grown ZnO nanorods, while after annealing the A line is originated from FX-1LO solely.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: Nominally undoped ZnO nanorods were grown by a conventional vapor phase transport method using a mixture of ZnO (99.99 %) and graphite (99.9 %) powder (weight ratio 2:1) as the source materials. Prior to growth, ZnO thin film was deposited on a Si (111) substrate by pulsed laser deposition as the seed layer. The growth of nanorods was carried out at 950 °C and 8 Torr for 45 min, using mixed argon (99 sccm) and oxygen (1 sccm) as the carrier gas. This procedure produces aligned ZnO nanorods with average diameter and length of about 600 nm and 11 μm, respectively [9]. The as-grown sample was then annealed in nitrogen at 800 °C for 20 min by rapid thermal annealing (RTP-300 equipment) at a heating rate of 160 °C s−1.

The impurities in the nanorods were analyzed using a time-of-flight mass spectrometer (Ion TOF-SIMS V). In order to take an accurate analysis of the metal impurities in our sample, we used O− as the primary sputtering ion (positive ion mode). Temperature-dependent PL measurements were performed on a fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh Instruments FLS920) ranging from 13 to 300 K with a closed-cycle helium cryostat. Ensembles of ZnO nanorods were excited by He-Cd laser operating at 325 nm. The resolution of the PL spectra is 0.05 nm (∼0.5 meV in the ZnO NBE region).

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the low-temperature (13 K) PL spectra of the as-grown and annealed ZnO nanorods. In the FX and bound exciton (BX) region (3.34–3.39 eV), the as-grown nanorods show FX recombination at 3.376 eV and neutral donor bound exciton (D0X) emission at 3.361 eV, with a relative large linewidth. After annealing, the spectra are well resolved and four more excitonic lines at 3.372, 3.367, 3.357 and 3.343 eV can be clearly observed. Interestingly, the 3.357 eV emission with a linewidth of 1.7 meV becomes dominant. The great reduction of linewidth of the excitonic lines indicates marked improvement of the crystal quality after annealing. The 3.372 and 3.367 eV lines are attributed to exciton bound to ionized donors [3], while the 3.343 eV line is attributed to exciton bound to structural defects [4].
Fig. 1
Low-temperature (13 K) PL spectra of the as-grown and annealed ZnO nanorods. (a) 3.34–3.40 eV region; (b) 3.06–3.34 eV region. XX in (a) represents biexcitonic emission. The dotted line in (b) denotes the predicted energy (3.285 eV) of the LO phonon replica of the 3.357 eV emission. The intensity of the spectra has been normalized to the strongest peak (D0X for as-grown and XX for annealed). The intensity of the as-grown sample has been multiplied by a factor of 9.7

In the region below 3.33 eV, there are emissions of two electron satellites (TES) and phonon replica of exciton recombination. For the as-grown nanorods, a series of broad peaks at 3.311 (A line), 3.238, 3.164 and 3.092 eV are observed. These peaks are separated by the same energy spacing of ∼72 meV, which agrees well with the LO phonon energy in ZnO. For the annealed nanorods, much more peaks are resolved. It shows TES of BX at 3.326 eV [2], the A line (slightly red-shifted compared with the as-grown one) with several LO replicas at 3.307, 3.233, 3.161 and 3.085 eV, and the LO replica of BX around 3.29 eV.

The emission at 3.357 eV is very close in energy to the well-known I9 line in ZnO, which has been attributed to excitons bound to In impurities [2]. However, it is surprising that the 3.357 eV line becomes dominant after annealing because introduction of In impurity during annealing is not expected. To verify the origin of the 3.357-eV emission in our sample, we measured the metal impurities in both the as-grown and annealed nanorods by SIMS, as shown in Fig. 2. As expected, the In impurity in both samples is below the detection limit, suggesting that the 3.357-eV emission is unlikely due to recombination of excitons bound to neutral In donors. This is supported by the feature of the band around 3.29 eV. Careful analysis of the 3.29-eV band indicates that it actually consists of two peaks at 3.294 and 3.289 eV, as shown in Fig. 1, which are exactly the LO replicas of the 3.367 and 3.361 eV lines. However, the LO replica of the 3.357 eV line, expected at 3.285 eV, is missing. These results strongly suggest that the 3.357-eV emission is not bound exciton in nature. Compared with FX, the energy of the 3.357-eV emission is lowered by 19 meV, which agrees well with the reported binding energy of biexciton in ZnO [10–13]. It is generally admitted that the observation of biexcitonic emission is one of the most conclusive criteria to demonstrate the crystal quality of semiconductors [11–13]. Bearing in mind that the crystal quality is indeed markedly improved after annealing, we suggest that the 3.357-eV emission in the present work can be attributed to biexciton recombination.
Fig. 2
SIMS spectra of the major donor impurities (H, Al, Ga, In) and possible acceptor impurities (Li, Na, K, N, Ag) in ZnO for the as-grown (black solid square) and annealed (red open square) nanorods. 64Zn is also plotted as a reference. The intensity has been normalized to 64Zn atom. The concentration of In impurity is below the detection limit in both samples. Other possible acceptor impurities such as P, As, Sb are not detected in both samples and hence not plotted

The origin of the A line around 3.31 eV in ZnO has been a controversial topic for a long time. Recent studies [7, 8, 14] suggested that two main candidates, namely FA transition and FX-1LO, are responsible for the A line. These two transitions have different luminescence lineshape and temperature dependence of peak energy. Stacking faults were convincingly demonstrated as the acceptors involved in FA [7], and the competition between FA and FX-1LO was suggested to make the identification more complicated and difficult [8].

In our work, it is interesting to find that the A line shows different lineshape and peak energy after annealing. At 13 K, the peak energy of FX-1LO (E FX-LO) is predicted at 3.306 eV according to [15]
1
$$ E_{\mathrm{FX}\mbox{-}\mathrm{LO}}(T) = E_\mathrm{FX}(T) - \hbar \omega_\mathrm{LO} + 1.5k_\mathrm{B}T, $$ where E FX is the free exciton energy, ħω LO the LO phonon energy, and k B the Boltzmann constant. The predicted energy agrees with the observed line at 3.307 eV in Fig. 1 very well. For the as-grown sample, however, the 3.311-eV emission cannot be attributed to FX-1LO solely because of the large deviation of peak energy. Kurbanov and Kang [16] found that the A-line and FX-1LO emission bands can be well distinguished at low temperatures under low excitation intensities. To determine the nature of the emission near 3.31 eV, temperature-dependent PL spectra for the as-grown and annealed nanorods were plotted in Fig. 3(a) and (b). The temperature dependence of energy difference between FX and the A line, E FX−E
A , for both the as-grown and annealed samples, can then be acquired and is plotted in Fig. 4. For comparison, we also plot in Fig. 4 the predicted energy difference of E FX−E FX-1LO and E FX−E FA as a function of temperature. For FX-1LO transition, the peak energy as a function of T is predicted by Eq. (1). While for FA transition, it is predicted by [11]
2
$$ E_{\mathrm{F}A}(T) = E_\mathrm{g}(T) - E_\mathrm{acceptor} + 0.5k_\mathrm{B}T. $$ For the as-grown nanorods, the data can be divided into two regions. At temperatures below ∼100 K, the energy difference follows the FA model [11]. While at temperatures above 100 K, the data are close to those predicted by FX-1LO model [15]. For the annealed nanorods, the data are in agreement with the predicted value for FX-1LO. The slight discrepancy at temperatures above 100 K may result from the approximation of Eq. (1). In fact, Eq. (1) should be more precisely written as [15] E FX-LO(T)=E FX(T)−ħω LO+(p+0.5)k B T. At low temperatures, p is assumed to be 1. At high temperatures, however, p can be less than 1. Therefore, the A line in the as-grown nanorods represents competition between FA and FX-LO, consistent with that reported by Tainoff et al. [8], while in the annealed nanorods the A line is attributed to FX-1LO only.
Fig. 3
Temperature-dependent PL spectra of the (a) as-grown and (b) annealed ZnO nanorods
Fig. 4
The peak energy difference between FX and the A line emissions (E FX−E
A ) as a function of temperature, for both the as-grown (black solid square) and annealed (red open square) nanorods. The T-dependent peak energy difference between FX and FX-LO (E FX−E FX-1LO, solid line) and FA transition (E FX−E FA , dashed line) is predicted using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively

The acceptor level involved in the FA transition is determined to be about 130 meV according to Eq. (2). We note that several acceptor impurities in ZnO, such as N [17], Li [18], Na [19], Sb [20] etc., have been reported to have acceptor level close to 130 meV. Therefore, it is necessary to discuss the nature of acceptors in our samples. We recall the emergence of D+X lines in the annealed sample (Fig. 1). It is a common feature for most III-V and II-VI semiconductors that increasing the acceptor doping decreases the PL intensity of D0X in favor of D+X [21]. To verify the increased (unintentional) acceptor doping during annealing, the possible acceptor impurities as well as the major donor impurities are checked by SIMS. As illustrated in Fig. 2, the concentration of H, Al and Ga donors decreases more or less after annealing, while the concentration of Na, N, and Ag acceptors increases. For Li and K acceptors, the concentration is almost not changed after annealing. Other possible acceptors such as P, As and Sb are not detected in both samples. The SIMS results indicate that the concentration of total acceptor impurities is indeed increased after annealing. In contrast, the FA transition near 3.31 eV is missing after annealing. These results strongly indicate that the FA observed in the as-grown ZnO nanorods is NOT related to those acceptor impurities. Bearing in mind that the crystal quality is significantly improved after annealing, as indicated by the emergence of biexciton emission and decreased linewidth of excitonic emissions, one can reasonably attribute the FA to stacking faults, in line with the results of Schirra et al. [7]. The results indicate that the annealing improves the crystal quality at least by reducing stacking faults in the nanorods. Correlation between the A-line intensity and annealing-induced structural defects has been reported by Kurbanov et al. [22] in ZnO nanocrystals. More importantly, the present study suggests that the emission around 3.31 eV serves as an optical signature for the change of stacking faults density in ZnO, and it is possible to monitor such change easily by low-temperature PL measurements combined with delicate analysis.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, temperature-dependent PL and trace metal analysis have been used to investigate the annealing effects on the 3.31-eV emission (A line) in ZnO nanorods. The as-grown nanorods show broad exciton and A line emissions. After annealing, the PL intensity is greatly enhanced and the linewidth is significantly reduced, indicating improved crystal quality. Annealing also results in a red shift of 4 meV of the A line. Temperature-dependent analysis indicates that the A line in the as-grown nanorods is a result of competition between FA and FX-1LO transitions, while in the annealed nanorods the A line is attributed to FX-1LO only. Annealing also results in increase of unintentional acceptor impurities. However, those acceptor impurities are not responsible for the FA emission. The significantly improved crystal quality after annealing indicates that the acceptor involved in the FA transition is stacking faults.
